solution_line_template: After the first hour of work, he has distributed newspapers to {first_hour_fraction}*{total_homes} = <<{first_hour_fraction}*{total_homes}={homes_distributed_first_hour}>>{homes_distributed_first_hour} homes

The number of homes that still need newspapers is {total_homes}-{homes_distributed_first_hour} = <<{total_homes}-{homes_distributed_first_hour}={remaining_homes_after_first_hour}>>{remaining_homes_after_first_hour}

Two hours later, the number of homes he has distributed newspapers to is {second_period_percentage} * {remaining_homes_after_first_hour} = <<{second_period_percentage}*{remaining_homes_after_first_hour}={homes_distributed_second_period}>>{homes_distributed_second_period} homes.

The number of homes he still needs to distribute newspapers to is {remaining_homes_after_first_hour}-{homes_distributed_second_period} = <<{remaining_homes_after_first_hour}-{homes_distributed_second_period}={homes_still_need_distribution}>>{homes_still_need_distribution} homes
